metadata.titleEn: Tree ring width and reconstructed precipitation soil water condition data series of the Northeastern Tibetan Plateau and dating data of the Delingha Area (1580B.C.-2006A.D.)
metadata.description: This dataset contains monthly 0.05°×0.05° (1982, 1985, 1990, 1995, and 2000) and 0.01°×0.01° (2005, 2010, 2015 and 2017) LST products in Qilian Mountain Area. The dataset was produced based on SW algorithm by AVHRR BT from thermal infrared channels (CH4: 10.5µm to 11.3µm; CH5: 11.5µm to 12.5µm) at a resolution of 0.05°, MYD21A1 LST products at a resolution of 0.01° along with some auxiliary datasets. The auxiliary datasets include IGBP land cover type, AVHRR NDVI products, Modern Era Retrospective-Analysis for Research and Applications-2 (MERRA-2) reanalysis data, ASTER GED, Lat/Lon and the Julian Day information.
metadata.instructions:
File Naming Convention: YYYYMM.tiff (YYYY: year, MM: month)
Data Version：V1.0
Projection：+proj=longlat +datum=WGS84 +no_defs
Data Format: GeoTIFF, 1100rows×1800columes (0.01°×0.01°), 220 rows×360 columes (0.05°×0.05°)
LST Unit: K
LST Valid Range：240-340
Filled Value：0

background: The snow water equivalent (SWE) is an important parameter of surface hydrological and climate systems, and it has a profound impact on Arctic amplification and climate change. In the land region above 45◦N, the existing SWE products are associated with a limited time span and limited spatial coverage, and the spatial resolution is coarse, which greatly limits the application of SWE data in cryosphere change and climate change studies. The IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change) AR6 (Sixth Assessment Report) notes that the Northern Hemisphere spring snow cover has greatly decreased since 1950, and the feedback effect of the climate system caused by this reduction is extremely large. At present, there are many forms of SWE data in the world. According to type, these data can be divided into site observational SWE, remote sensing SWE, reanalysis SWE, data assimilation SWE, and model simulation SWE. However, the time ranges of AMSR-E and AMSR-E2 SWE are only from 2003 to the present, which is lacking in terms of time series. Although the reanalysis SWE data have good spatial and temporal continuity and high data integrity, their accuracy is poor, and the mean absolute error (MAE) is 0.65. For remote sensing SWE, the spatiotemporal characteristics of different passive microwave SWE data differ significantly due to differences in sensors or retrieval algorithms. In summary, although there are a variety of SWE data in the world, the data quality is uncertain. Previous studies have shown that all kinds of SWE data in the Northern Hemisphere have advantages and disadvantages, and none of these data perform well in all aspects. An effective method was used in a study by Pulliainen et al. (2020), who applied a bias correction to GlobSnow and reanalysis data products based on SWE snow course measurements to obtain improved estimates on annual peak snow mass and SWE in the Northern Hemisphere.
research objective: In this study, utilizing the ridge regression model (RRM) of a machine learning algorithm, we integrated various existing SWE products to generate a spatiotemporally seamless and high-precision RRM SWE product. In summary, based on the existing SWE data products, combining a machine learning algorithm to fuse multisource SWE data is an effective method to prepare SWE products with long time series and large spatial scales and retain the advantages of single SWE data products.
challenges: However, there are great differences among existing SWE products. The SWE data from stations and meteorological observations cannot meet the needs of hydrometeorological and climate change research. This is mainly because SWE from stations is discontinuous in time series and severely missing. There are great differences among remote sensing SWE, reanalysis SWE data, data assimilation SWE, and observational SWE. In summary, although there are a variety of SWE data in the world, the data quality is uncertain. However, the simple multisource data average cannot highlight the advantages of high-precision data, and it is easily affected by the weight ratio of low-precision data, which reduces the accuracy of fused data.
methods: In this study, we utilized ERA-Interim SWE data, GLDAS SWE data, GlobSnow SWE data, AMSR-E/AMSR2 SWE data, and ERA5-Land SWE data as the original input datasets for the fusion data. The missing parts of the ERA-Interim SWE, AMSR-E/AMSR2 SWE, and GlobSnow SWE data were filled by the spatiotemporal interpolation method. The HSSC dataset and Russian snow survey data were used as training sample data of “true SWE”, and the effect of altitude on the algorithm was also considered. Thus, we prepared a set of spatiotemporal seamless SWE datasets (RRM SWE) covering the land region above 45 ◦N from 1979 to 2019. In this study, we utilize the ridge regression model of a machine learning algorithm to fuse ERA-Interim SWE data, GLDAS SWE data, GlobSnow SWE data, AMSR-E/AMSR2 SWE data, and ERA5-Land SWE data to generate a set of new RRM SWE datasets.
dataset: The HSSC dataset (Pulliainen et al., 2020) and Russian snow survey data (Bulygina et al., 2011) were used as training sample data of “true SWE”. In this study, we utilized ERA-Interim SWE data (Dee et al., 2011), GLDAS SWE data (Rodell et al., 2004), GlobSnow SWE data (Luojus et al., 2021), AMSR-E/AMSR2 SWE data (Tedesco and Jeyaratnam, 2019), and ERA5-Land SWE data (Muñoz Sabater, 2019) as the original input datasets for the fusion data.
findings: The results show that it is feasible to utilize a ridge regression model based on a machine learning algorithm to prepare SWE products on a global scale. The accuracy of the RRM SWE dataset is improved by 28 %, 22 %, 37 %, 11 %, and 11 % compared with the original AMSR-E/AMSR2 (SWE), ERA-Interim SWE, Global Land Data Assimilation System (GLDAS) SWE, GlobSnow SWE, and ERA5-Land SWE datasets, respectively, and it has a higher spatial resolution. This method has good stability, is extremely suitable for the production of snow datasets with large spatial scales, and can be easily extended to the preparation of other snow datasets. The RRM SWE product is expected to provide more accurate SWE data for the hydrological model and climate model and provide data support for cryosphere change and climate change studies.

Verification.Question: Can machine learning algorithms, such as ridge regression models, effectively integrate multiple SWE products to achieve high-precision and seamless SWE datasets?

Disjunctive.Question: Which data fusion technique for SWE data is more effective in improving accuracy: simple averaging or machine learning algorithms like ridge regression models?
Disjunctive.Answer: machine learning algorithms like ridge regression models

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection method is used to obtain tree ring width and precipitation reconstruction data in the northeastern Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Where are the tree ring width datasets collected in the northeastern Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?

Example.Question: What is an example of a methodological approach to fuse multiple snow water equivalent (SWE) datasets to improve accuracy in climate change research?
Example.Answer: A methodological approach involves using the ridge regression model, a machine learning algorithm, to integrate various SWE data products such as ERA-Interim, GLDAS, GlobSnow, AMSR-E/AMSR2, and ERA5-Land. This fusion creates a spatiotemporally seamless and high-precision SWE dataset, which enhances accuracy by leveraging the strengths of each dataset.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how missing data in snow water equivalent datasets can be addressed to enhance their utility in climatic studies?
Example.Answer: Missing data in snow water equivalent datasets, such as those from ERA-Interim, AMSR-E/AMSR2, and GlobSnow, can be addressed using spatiotemporal interpolation methods. These methods fill gaps in data coverage and ensure continuity, which is crucial for accurate hydrometeorological and climate change analysis.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key characteristics of tree ring width data collected from the northeastern Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: site-specific station data, annual sample sizes, width indices, measured in a laboratory setting, no units for width indices, sample size measured as a count of samples

Feature Specification.Question: What are the essential attributes of reconstructed precipitation and soil moisture conditions in historical data series?
Feature Specification.Answer: annual precipitation from the previous July to the current June, soil relative humidity for specific months, plant growth water demand, actual evaporation amounts

Quantification.Question: What percentage improvement in accuracy is observed when using a ridge regression model to prepare a snow water equivalent product compared to the original datasets?
How many years does the tree-ring width dataset from Delingha cover?

Definition.Question: What does 'tree ring width index' mean in the context of dendrochronology data collection?
Definition.Answer: The 'tree ring width index' is a dimensionless measure calculated from tree ring width data, used to standardize or normalize the data across different samples or sites, enabling comparison and reconstruction of past climatic conditions such as precipitation and soil moisture.

Definition.Question: What does 'ridge regression model' mean in the context of machine learning algorithms for data fusion?
Definition.Answer: The 'ridge regression model' is a type of machine learning algorithm used to integrate various datasets, such as SWE data, by applying regularization techniques to handle multicollinearity and improve the precision of the fused dataset, resulting in a high-accuracy product that retains the advantages of individual data sources.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when collecting data for tree ring width indices versus snow water equivalent datasets?
Comparison.Answer: The challenges in collecting data for tree ring width indices involve maintaining strict adherence to operational protocols to ensure data accuracy. Conversely, SWE datasets face challenges due to the discontinuity and missing data in time series, variations among different data sources, and the need to integrate multisource data without compromising the accuracy due to low-precision inputs.

Interpretation.Question: What data collection methods can be inferred from the use of reanalysis and remote sensing datasets in generating comprehensive data products in this area?
Interpretation.Answer: Data collection methods in this domain involve the use of spatiotemporal interpolation to fill gaps in datasets and leveraging remote sensing and reanalysis data, which provide continuity and comprehensive coverage despite the inherent variations in accuracy and temporal scope.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity of integrating different types of SWE data products for creating a high-precision dataset?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complexity arises from the great differences among existing SWE products, such as remote sensing SWE, reanalysis SWE data, data assimilation SWE, and observational SWE. Each type has its own strengths and weaknesses, and the simple multisource data average does not effectively leverage high-precision data, potentially reducing the accuracy of the fused data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the temporal discontinuity of SWE data from meteorological stations a significant challenge for climate change research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The temporal discontinuity of SWE data from meteorological stations presents challenges because such data are often discontinuous in time series and severely missing. This limits the ability to conduct comprehensive hydrometeorological and climate change research that requires continuous, high-quality data over time.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the uncertainty in the quality of SWE data globally, and how does it affect its application in cryosphere change studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The uncertainty in SWE data quality globally is caused by differences in sensors, retrieval algorithms, and the inherent limitations of each data type, such as site observational, remote sensing, reanalysis, and data assimilation SWE. This variability affects its application in cryosphere change studies by complicating the interpretation of data trends and reducing confidence in the data's accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the discontinuity and missing data in observational SWE datasets impact hydrometeorological and climate change research?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Discontinuity and missing data in observational SWE datasets hinder their ability to meet the needs of hydrometeorological and climate change research. This limitation affects the time series continuity and accuracy, reducing the reliability of SWE data for these studies.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using spatiotemporal interpolation methods to fill missing parts of SWE datasets for data fusion processes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using spatiotemporal interpolation methods to fill missing parts of SWE datasets allows for more complete data fusion, leading to the creation of a spatiotemporally seamless SWE dataset. This approach enhances data continuity and integrity, improving the overall quality and applicability of SWE products for cryosphere and climate change studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of integrating various existing SWE products using a ridge regression model in snow water equivalent data collection?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to generate a spatiotemporally seamless and high-precision SWE product that combines the advantages of multiple SWE data sources, aiming for long time series and large spatial scales, and to improve the quality and applicability of SWE data in cryosphere change and climate change studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What drives the need for high spatial resolution and improved accuracy in SWE datasets for climate and hydrological research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: High spatial resolution and improved accuracy in SWE datasets are needed to better capture the spatiotemporal variability of snow cover and water resources, which are critical for understanding and modeling the impacts of climate change, enhancing hydrological models, and supporting decision-making in water management and policy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are various snow water equivalent (SWE) datasets integrated using machine learning algorithms to achieve a seamless and high-precision product?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The integration process involves using a ridge regression model (RRM) to fuse multiple SWE datasets. The missing parts of the original datasets are filled using spatiotemporal interpolation, and training sample data are used to calibrate the model, considering factors such as altitude.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and methodologies enable the integration of multiple SWE data types to generate a seamless and high-precision dataset?
Enablement.Answer: Utilizing a ridge regression model of a machine learning algorithm allows for the integration of various existing SWE products, such as ERA-Interim, GLDAS, GlobSnow, AMSR-E/AMSR2, and ERA5-Land SWE data. Spatiotemporal interpolation methods are applied to fill in missing data, and training samples from datasets like HSSC and Russian snow survey data help create a spatiotemporal seamless dataset, considering factors such as altitude.

Enablement.Question: How do specific data collection techniques in tree ring studies enable the reconstruction of past precipitation and soil moisture conditions over long periods?
Enablement.Answer: Data collection techniques in tree ring studies involve laboratory measurements and strict adherence to operational protocols to gather samples and data. The tree ring width indices and dating data are collected from specific sites, allowing for the reconstruction of precipitation and soil moisture conditions over extended historical periods, spanning from 1580 B.C. to 2006 A.D.

Enablement.Question: What technological and methodological advancements enable the improvement of SWE data quality and spatial resolution for global climate studies?
Enablement.Answer: The development of advanced machine learning algorithms, such as ridge regression models, enables the fusion of multisource SWE data to produce datasets with improved spatial resolution and accuracy. This approach addresses the limitations of single-source SWE data products by integrating high-precision data while mitigating the impact of lower-precision sources.

Expectation.Question: Why might integrating various datasets improve the accuracy of precipitation and soil moisture reconstruction in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Integrating various datasets can enhance accuracy by combining strengths and compensating for weaknesses of individual datasets, similar to how the ridge regression model in machine learning algorithms effectively fuses multisource snow water equivalent (SWE) data to improve precision and spatial resolution.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise in maintaining the spatiotemporal continuity of tree-ring width data over a period of 3500 years?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in maintaining spatiotemporal continuity over such a long period may include discontinuities and gaps in data, similar to those found in snow water equivalent (SWE) datasets, where station data is often discontinuous and missing, hindering comprehensive climate change research.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the effectiveness of using machine learning algorithms, like the ridge regression model, for integrating various snow water equivalent (SWE) data products to enhance data quality?
Judgmental.Answer: Utilizing a machine learning algorithm, such as the ridge regression model, is an effective method for integrating various SWE data products. It allows for the preparation of SWE products with long time series and large spatial scales, retaining the advantages of single SWE data products, and improving the accuracy of the datasets.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the challenges associated with differences among existing SWE products, and what strategies might be employed to address these differences?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges associated with existing SWE products include discontinuity in time series, severe data gaps, and significant differences among remote sensing, reanalysis, data assimilation, and observational SWE. To address these differences, integrating SWE data using a machine learning approach and applying bias correction based on snow course measurements can provide improved estimates and address data quality issues.

Judgmental.Question: In your view, what are the potential benefits and limitations of utilizing site observational, remote sensing, reanalysis, and data assimilation SWE data for hydrometeorological and climate change research?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential benefits of utilizing these diverse SWE data sources include improved spatial and temporal coverage and enhanced data integrity. However, limitations arise from the discontinuity and missing data in observational SWE and the varying accuracy and spatiotemporal characteristics of remote sensing and reanalysis SWE data. A fusion approach using machine learning could mitigate these limitations by improving data accuracy and quality.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the integration of different SWE data sources can improve the quality of a dataset for climate change studies.
Assertion.Answer: By utilizing a ridge regression model with machine learning algorithms, various existing SWE products are integrated to generate a high-precision, spatiotemporally seamless dataset. This approach retains the advantages of individual SWE data products and improves accuracy compared to original datasets.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced when collecting and using snow water equivalent data for hydrometeorological research.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include discontinuous time series and severe data gaps in station-based SWE observations. Differences among remote sensing, reanalysis, data assimilation, and observational SWE data also pose challenges, affecting data quality and reliability.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges faced in integrating different sources of snow water equivalent (SWE) data to create a high-precision dataset.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in integrating different sources of SWE data include the discontinuity and severe missing data from station observations, significant differences among remote sensing, reanalysis, data assimilation, and observational SWE data, and the quality uncertainty of existing SWE data. The simple multisource data average approach does not effectively highlight the advantages of high-precision data and can be negatively impacted by low-precision data, reducing the overall accuracy of the fused dataset.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest potential datasets and methods for improving the accuracy and spatial resolution of snow water equivalent (SWE) products on a global scale.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for improving the accuracy and spatial resolution of SWE products include ERA-Interim SWE data, GLDAS SWE data, GlobSnow SWE data, AMSR-E/AMSR2 SWE data, and ERA5-Land SWE data. Methods such as using a ridge regression model of a machine learning algorithm to fuse these datasets, considering the effect of altitude, and using training sample data like the HSSC dataset and Russian snow survey data can lead to more accurate and spatiotemporally seamless SWE datasets.
